content:
• Friday, August 7, 2015
  • PXLW

    Pixelworks closes down 13.6% after pricing offering at major discount

    • Pixelworks (NASDAQ:PXLW) closed at $4.76 today after pricing its stock offering (first announced yesterday afternoon) at $4.75, nearly 14% below Thursday's close.
    • 3.25M shares are being sold, with the underwriter having a 487.5K-share overallotment option. Not counting the overallotment option, gross proceeds are set to total $15.4M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:58 PM
  • JD

    JD.com closes lower in spite of Q2 beat; Q3 guidance in-line

    • JD.com's (NASDAQ:JD) Q2 revenue of RMB45.9B ($7.4B, +61% Y/Y) beat an RMB44.5B consensus, and EPS of -RMB0.01 ($0.00) beat an -RMB0.13 consensus. Q3 revenue guidance of RMB43.2B-RMB44.7B (+49%-54% Y/Y) is in-line with an RMB44.3B consensus.
    • JD's GMV rose 82% Y/Y in Q2 to $18.5B - a slower growth rate than Q1's 99%, but still well above the 40% GMV growth Alibaba's Chinese marketplaces saw in calendar Q1. GMV for the JD Mall marketplace rose 92%. Annual active customer accounts rose 72% to 118M, and fulfilled orders 87% to 305.6M (47% via mobile).
    • Cost of revenue rose 57% Y/Y, slightly less than revenue growth of 61% and implying a 12.8% gross margin. Fulfillment spend rose 62% to $0.5B, as JD continued expanding its fulfillment infrastructure (viewed as a differentiator) to smaller cities. Marketing spend rose 86% to $0.3B, tech/content spend 87% to $126.6M, and G&A spend 67% to $69.3M.
    • Shares fell 2.3% in regular trading to $32.07.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:24 PM
  • FOX

    Fox debate draws crush of 24M viewers; Stewart gets 3.5M for finale

    • A pair of cable TV numbers highlights from last night: First, coverage by Fox News (FOX +4.5%, FOXA +2.8%) of the first Republican primary debate drew a giant 24M viewers, with the help of unpredictable poll leader Donald Trump.
    • That's the most-watched primary debate ever, and far more than the most-watched GOP debate of the 2012 race (7.6M viewers). Interest was high with a cavalcade of candidates (10 of the 17 declared candidates in the crowded prime-time debate) and expectations for controversy, or at least brashness, from Trump.
    • The next GOP debate is set for Sept. 16 on CNN (NYSE:TWX) -- likely fervently hoping for a Trump boost.
    • Meanwhile, on Comedy Central (VIA +2.6%, VIAB +3.1%), Jon Stewart's last episode of The Daily Show drew 3.5M viewers, making it the No. 2 Daily Show ever in viewer count. Only an October 2008 episode with Barack Obama drew more, with 3.6M.
    • Of the 3.5M last night, 1.8M were adults 18-49. It was also the show's most social episode ever, Nielsen said, with 117K Twitter users sending 233.4K tweets about the show, seen by 4.3M people.
    • The success was a double-edged sword for Viacom: A nice coup, but it highlights the challenge of replacing Stewart with Trevor Noah after Comedy Central (and Viacom nets in general) faced ratings headwinds this past season.
    • Previously: Viacom faces heavy risk in late-night host replacements (Apr. 16 2015)
    • Previously: Noah succeeding Stewart, taking fake news helm at Comedy Central (Mar. 30 2015)
    • Previously: Is Jon Stewart worth $100M to Viacom? (Feb. 12 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:21 PM | 1 Comment
  • SKUL

    Skullcandy closes up 9.3% after mixed results, EPS guidance hike

    • In addition to slightly beating Q2 EPS estimates (while slightly missing on revenue), Skullcandy (NASDAQ:SKUL) hiked its 2015 EPS guidance to $0.41-$0.43 (above a $0.39 consensus) from $0.36-$0.40.
    • Full-year revenue growth guidance of 13%-15% (in-line with a 13.8% consensus) is reiterated. Q3 guidance is for 17%-19% revenue growth and EPS of $0.07-$0.08 vs. a consensus of 13.9% growth and $0.12.
    • Boosting Q2 EPS: Gross margin was 42.8%, down 220 bps Y/Y (forex and a mix shift towards gaming products are blamed) but up 230 bps Q/Q. In addition, SG&A spend rose a moderate 4% Y/Y to $23.8M.
    • U.S. sales rose 5% Y/Y to $58M, while international sales rose 16% to $16.7M. Skullcandy's Astro gaming headset line was an area of strength.
    • Shares jumped to $7.98 in regular trading. They went into earnings just $0.27 above a 52-week low of $7.03.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:53 PM
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate +6.4% as analysts stay bullish

    • Lions Gate (LGF) rebounded from yesterday's losses (down 5.3% yesterday and more after its postmartket revenue miss) to finish up 6.4% today, as reactions took in the impact of its light film slate (and an all-time high backlog).
    • Stifel Nicolaus reiterated its Buy rating, as did B. Riley.
    • B. Riley's Eric Wold said EBITDA upside was impressive during a seasonally weak time -- "which, we believe, helps to demonstrate the strength of the TV Production segment visibility and ability to monetize key franchises even during an uneventful theatrical release quarter."
    • We continue to believe the studio is well positioned to drive EBITDA higher in the coming years (especially into FY17)," he wrote, "with a strong balance sheet and tax position that can provide opportunities to accelerate growth further through acquisitions (further leveraging the company’s infrastructure).
    • With cash and credit of about $1B (not to mention attractive Canadian tax status), Lions Gate is in good position to take advantage of media disruption to go after qualified acquisition candidates, he says.
    • He has a $45 price target on the stock -- almost 20% upside from today's close of $37.61.
    • Previously: Lions Gate off 3.8% after hours as revenues come up short (Aug. 06 2015)
    • Previously: Disney down again, -5% amid broad media sell-off (Aug. 06 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: OCN +13.1%. ENPH +9.6%. CWEI +9.1%. SEMG +8.9%. ENTA +7.0%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: CVT -13.5%. MIFI -12.7%. EXTR -10.5%. BRKS -9.5%. SPPI -6.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 7 Comments
  • VLTC

    Voltari exiting mobile ads, entering real estate; shares +23.8%

    • In an SEC filing, Voltari (OTC:VLTC) states its board has "committed the Company to a transformation plan pursuant to which, among other things, the Company intends to exit its mobile marketing and advertising business and enter into the business of acquiring, financing and leasing commercial real estate properties."
    • As "the first step" in this transformation, Voltari has bought a real estate parcel in Long Branch, NJ for $3.63M. JPMorgan currently has a lease for the property that expires in June 2020; average annual rental income is expected to be $203K.
    • Also: Voltari has obtained a $10M loan facility from an affiliate of majority owner Carl Icahn. Borrowings will "bear interest at a rate equal to the greater of the LIBOR rate plus 350 basis points, per annum, and 3.75%, per annum."
    • Voltari has jumped to $9.17 in AH trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:30 PM | 7 Comments
  • SREV

    ServiceSource closes up 19.3% after Q2 beat; job cuts lift EPS

    • ServiceSource (NASDAQ:SREV) surged to $5.70 today after delivering a healthy Q2 beat. On its earnings call (transcript), the recurring revenue management software/services firm guided for Q3 revenue of $57M-$60M and EPS of -$0.05 to -$0.07 vs. a consensus of $57.6M and -$0.08.
    • Job cuts/cost controls provided a boost to Q2 EPS: Operating expenses fell 27% Y/Y to $23M. They're expected to be in a range of 24%-25% in Q3. Also: Gross margin rose 410 bps Y/Y to 33.9%. Q3 GM is expected to be in a 25%-28% range vs. 27.3% a year ago. 15 transactions were recorded in Q2, of which 11 for managed services deals.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:20 PM
  • ANET

    Arista posts 3.1% gain after Q2 beat, strong guidance; Street likes cloud growth

    • Arista (NYSE:ANET) closed above $84 today after beating Q2 estimates and guiding for Q3 revenue of $208M-$212M, above a $206.4M consensus.
    • A slew of analysts offered positive reactions today, often while expressing satisfaction with the strong growth Arista reported seeing among Web/cloud service providers - recent capex budget cuts by Google, Facebook, and Apple had put investors on edge. Deutsche's Brian Modoff argues a consensus for mid-20s 2016 revenue growth could be conservative if Arista continues seeing 30%+ growth related to cloud data center buildouts.
    • Wells Fargo's Jess Lubert thinks the Q3 outlook might be conservative, and "may embed an added degree of conservatism" given Q3 is new CFO Ita Brennan's first full quarter.Â  RBC's Mark Sue sees plenty of room for international sales (23% of revenue) to grow.
    • During the earnings call, Arista spent a decent amount of time talking up the potential of its just-launched CloudVision network management/automation software platform. CloudVision, offered as a subscription-based add-on to Arista's EOS OS, is expected to contribute meaningfully to 2016/2017 sales.
    • Boosting Q2 EPS: Gross margin was 65.8%, down 30 bps Q/Q and 210 bps Y/Y, but above guidance of 63%-65%. Q3 GM guidance is also at 63%-65%. GAAP operating expenses rose 52% Y/Y to $95M.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM
  • ZNGA

    Zynga climbs to 7.8% gain as analysts look to heavy Q4 slate

    • Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) finished up 7.8% today, on triple average volume, as Wall Street reactions to its Q2 earnings trickled in.
    • Earlier, the stock saw strong volume in premarket trading after Benchmark upgraded it to Buy. Wedbush reiterated its own Buy rating, while Robert w. Baird reiterated its Hold rating.
    • Bank of America's Justin Post noted that Zynga's bookings seem to be "somewhat stabilizing," but pointed to active user base as a concern. He said Zynga's below-consensus guidance is somewhat conservative given the company's labor-cost savings initiatives, and said there's room for "stock enthusiasm" heading into 2016 if the company can produce hits.
    • Morgan Stanley also pointed to the importance of Q4, which is taking the brunt of the release slate after what will be a soft Q3. Metrics in geo-lock for Dawn of Titans (hitting worldwide in Q4) were encouraging as users averaged twice the sessions played vs. Empires and Allies.
    • Previously: Zynga up 2.9% as Benchmark upgrades to Buy (Aug. 07 2015)
    • Previously: Zynga off 1.6% after hours, issues light Q3 guidance (Aug. 06 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:49 PM | 3 Comments
  • TNET

    TriNet posts 6.4% gain after SVP discloses purchase

    • TriNet (NYSE:TNET) SVP/chief legal officer Brady Mickelsen has disclosed he bought 10K shares on Thursday at $17.37.
    • The purchase came two days after TriNet plunged in response to a Q2 miss. Shares rallied today to 18.52.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM
  • SAAS

    InContact tumbles 28%; still confident in recurring growth

    • InContact (NASDAQ:SAAS) opened down significantly, and shed even more through the day on 10 times average volume to finish down 28.4% after yesterday's earnings report where it swung to a net loss.
    • On the company's earnings call, CEO Paul Jarman said management was confident they could grow recurring software revenues above 30% despite the Q2 bookings growth being just 3%, pointing to the importance of same-store sales, the actual dollar value of bookings growing faster than bookings themselves, and confidence in the second-half pipeline.
    • "We've expanded our partner channel, we've hired additional salespeople, and we are working on a number of significant opportunities, some of which moved from second to third quarter," Jarman said.
    • A couple of bigger deals moved out of Q2, Jarman elaborated, but "some have closed and some are closing" now in Q3, for "significant" numbers of seats compared to average.
    • Previously: InContact swings to loss, grows revenue 29% (Aug. 06 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM

  • Weekly ETF Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: GAZ +4.31%. UNG +2.84%. TLT +1.48%. FXA +1.23%. XLU +.9%.
    • Losers: AMJ -8.59%. OIL -7.74%. EWZ -6.65%. USO -6.6%. BNO -6.6%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • SYA

    Symetra reportedly exploring sale; shares surge

    • Reuters reports Symetra Financial (NYSE:SYA) has been working with bankers in recent months to explore a sale, and has "spoken to several industry peers that have expressed interest."
    • Shares spiked shortly before the close, and finished up 9.4%. The report comes in a year that has seen a flurry of insurance industry mergers/acquisitions.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:06 PM
  • ENOC

    EnerNOC -20%, giving back yesterday's big gains

    • EnerNOC (ENOC -19.9%) rallied sharply yesterday after crushing Q2 earnings estimates, but today the stock has given back virtually all the gains, perhaps in the realization that the initial pop may been unsustainable or driven up by momentum traders more than long-term investors.
    • ENOC’s post-earnings gain was the best in more than two years after posting a much smaller than expected loss of $0.32/share, with Q3 revenue guidance of $224M-$239M exceeding by threefold the $72M in sales for the same period a year ago.
    • Analysts are now looking for annual revenues of $422M 2015 and $455M for 2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • CVC

    Cablevision call: No 'landslide' away from pay-TV bundle yet

    • Cablevision Systems (NYSE:CVC) spent the afternoon regaining ground from a decline after its Q2 earnings report. Shares are now down just 2.8% after declining as much as 7.8% in the morning.
    • On the company's earnings call today, CEO James Dolan says despite an avalanche of recent cord-cutting press, there won't be a "landslide" of customers dropping the traditional bundle in the near term. "I don't think the sky is falling quite yet."
    • But eventually more online content will become more appealing to customers as the traditional bundle increases in price, he said, putting a timeline to it: "My own prediction is it will be at least five years for 10% of the [pay TV] market to move, and 10 years for 30% of the market to move."
    • He also took a shot at Verizon, whose FiOS footprint has pressed Cablevision's territory: “The Verizon FiOS effect, if there ever was one, is, in our opinion, over ... To the extent that we’ve lost customers to FiOS, we believe they are usually promotional shoppers." He says Cablevision serves 3.1M customers, down from 3.3M in 2008, during which time Verizon has invested billions into building FiOS in greater New York.
    • Asked about repurchase resumption, CFO Brian Sweeney said the company sees the dividend as the primary return of capital, though they would look at opportunistic buyback in the future.
    • Previously: Cablevision -2% after report with solid Internet service growth (Aug. 07 2015)
    • Related: Cablevision Systems (CVC) James Lawrence Dolan on Q2 2015 Results - Earnings Call Transcript (Aug. 07 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 1 Comment
  • SMLP

    Summit Midstream sinks as distribution growth slows

    • Summit Midstream Partners (SMLP -7.3%) is sharply lower despite "decent" Q2 results with adjusted EBITDA of $54M and distributable cash flow of $40M in line with consensus, and declaring a $0.57 distribution/unit for Q2 (+9.6% Y/Y) which puts SMLP on track to meet its 7%-8% DPU growth guidance.
    • Today's drop echoes concerns that slammed Plains All American this week over distribution growth, as SMLP said in its earnings call that is lowering forward guidance for distribution growth to 4%-6% in the year ahead compared to previous guidance of 7%-8% growth.
    • Wunderlich's Jeff Birnbaum says SMLP is not covering 100% of its distributions with cash flow, calculating that the company is covering 95% in H2; the analyst lowers his price target to $34 from $37 but keeps his Buy rating.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM | 2 Comments
  • GOLD

    Barrick Gold upgraded at Barclays on ability to reduce debt

    • Barrick Gold (ABX +1.7%) is upgraded to Equal Weight from Underweight with a $10 price target at Barclays, which believes the miner's ability to reduce debt removes an overhang on the stock.
    • ABX's Q2 earnings report highlighted another group of non-core assets the miner intends to sell by year-end, which the firm thinks could generate proceeds of another $500M-$$700M.
    • ABX has indicated that proceeds from asset sales will be used to repay debt and based on its maturity schedule, Barclays believes the sales already announced plus guided cost savings and further sales will allow the company to repay all debt maturities to 2020.
    • With the decline in gold prices, ABX likely will find it difficult to generate positive free cash flow, so Barclays believes the announced dividend and cost cuts are both necessary and prudent.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM | 2 Comments
  • BOX

    Box up 8.9% following Oppenheimer upgrade, fresh Cramer defense

    • Citing its recent selloff, Oppenheimer has upgraded BOX to Outperform. The firm's target is $21.
    • Oppenheimer: "We believe customer additions remain solid and see increasing interest in [enterprise key management], which could mitigate price pressure concerns ... From the start we've been positive on Box's large and growing [addressable market], effective land-and-expand business model, and take-out possibility, but looked for a better entry point." The firm admits "there's some incremental concern" Microsoft could become a bigger competitor in time, in spite of its (Office 365-focused) partnership with Box.
    • Separately, Jim Cramer defended Box once again (previous) during last night's episode of Mad Money. "[Box] has really proven to be a battleground. Aaron Levie runs a good company, and the fact that this company is only [worth] $1.6 billion with the opportunity it has, you know what? I think the market is wrong on Box."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM | 3 Comments
  • AMBR

    Amber Road down 24.2% due to weak Q3/2015 guidance

    • Though Amber Road (NYSE:AMBR) beat Q2 estimates, it's guiding for Q3 revenue of $17.3M-$17.6M and EPS of -$0.20 to -$0.21 (below a consensus of $19M and -$0.14), and full-year revenue of $68M-$70M and EPS of -$0.73 to -$0.77 (below a consensus of $72.8M and -$0.60).
    • CEO Jim Preuninger: "During the second quarter, we saw ongoing momentum in the US mid-market and Asia but continued to experience subscription bookings weakness in the large enterprise space. This will impact our subscription and related professional services revenue in the back half of the year, and as a result, we are lowering our full year guidance."
    • Shares have plunged to new post-IPO lows. They also fell sharply following Amber Road's Q1 report.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM | 1 Comment
  • CTCM

    CTC Media -2% as profits tumble in tough ad market

    • Russia's CTC Media (NASDAQ:CTCM) is down 2% after a Q2 earnings report where it stayed profitable -- but net earnings declined 82% to $4.7M, after revenues were halved.
    • The company points to third-party reports that say the Russian TV ad market was down by 21% (in ruble terms) for the quarter. Forex issues played on results again; revenues dropped 50% in dollar terms, but just 25% in ruble terms.
    • Revenues did grow sequentially in dollar terms: total revenues up 17%, ad revenues up 16%.
    • With limited visibility as it billionaire Alisher Usmanov negotiates a controlling stake, the company won't declare a dividend for Q3 and isn't issuing full-year guidance.
    • Previously: CTC Media gives UTH Russia until Sept. 30 to seal $200M ownership bid (Jul. 24 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM
  • SUNEQ

    SunEdison down another 11.2% post-earnings; SolarCity down 7.6%

    • David Einhorn can't be pleased: SunEdison (SUNE) is now down 34% since posting mixed Q2 results and reiterating its full-year system delivery guidance on Thursday morning. Fellow U.S. solar play SolarCity (SCTY) is down 15% over that same span, though its overlap with SunEdison is limited outside of Vivint Solar (about to be acquired by SunEdison).
    • Credit Suisse has defended SunEdison amid the plunge, arguing there's “a fundamental disconnect between the stock performance and the ... stellar execution of the organic project development business that exceeded expectations on all metrics, ... increased disclosure to pacify liquidity concerns, and the company making the (right) decision to ensure accretive drop-down economics.”
    • During the earnings call (transcript), management was peppered with questions about solar/wind project ROIs, as well as future capital needs and SunEdison's ability to maintain its breakneck growth rate (the result of both internal financing/construction work and M&A). CFO Brian Wuebbels reiterated SunEdison's internal project development ops (i.e. the DevCo) expect to reach cash flow breakeven in 2016, and noted recent capital raises were oversubscribed.
    • SunEdison's Q2 results, guidance/details
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 32 Comments
  • VRNS

    Varonis up 13.7% after Q2 beat, strong customer adds

    • Three months after tumbling due to a Q1 miss and soft guidance, Varonis (NASDAQ:VRNS) has jumped thanks to a Q2 beat (moreso on EPS than revenue) delivered amid a backdrop of low expectations.
    • Q3 guidance is for revenue of $30.2M-$30.8M and EPS of -$0.16 to -$0.18 vs. a consensus of $30.6M and -$0.16. Full-year guidance is for revenue of $123.6M-$126.7M and EPS of -$0.60 to -$0.65 vs. a consensus of $124.3M and -$0.72.
    • Slower spending growth boosted EPS: After rising 36% Y/Y in Q1, GAAP operating expenses rose 23% in Q2. License revenue (drives future maintenance/services revenue) rose 11% to $16M; maintenance/services revenue rose 29% to $13.1M.
    • 258 new customers were added, up from 189 in Q1 and 206 a year ago. Varonis notes growing corporate cybersecurity spend is boosting demand for its unstructured data management software. "Most breaches today involve the theft of unstructured data, and it has become increasingly clear that organizations need to modernize their defenses by directly fortifying the controls around assets they need to protect."
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 2:28 PM
  • SUNW

    Solar3D down 10.2% post-earnings; backlog grows to $22.7M

    • Solar3D (SLTD) has tumbled below $4 after reporting Q2 revenue rose 94% Q/Q to $11M, and net loss narrowed to $122K from Q1's $1.4M. The solar project backlog rose to $22.7M (7.2MW) from $14.7M (4.6MW) at the end of Q1.
    • One potential area of concern: Gross margin fell to 31% from Q1's 34% in spite of the revenue growth; it was up from Q2 2014's 27% (off a much smaller revenue base). Operating expenses rose to $3.3M from Q1's $3M and Q2 2014's $1.3M. Solar3D's cash balance dropped by $1.9M Q/Q to $9.3M.
    • 6.3MW of solar systems were sold in Q2 vs. 5.5MW in Q1, and 3.7MW were installed vs. 1.6MW. A few notable deals have been announced since the end of Q2.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 2:07 PM | 3 Comments
  • DGLY

    Digital Ally down 11.6% after Q2 report; 2015 guidance isn't reiterated

    • Digital Ally's (NASDAQ:DGLY) Q2 revenue rose 33% Q/Q and 63% Y/Y to $5.6M. However, the company has declined to reiterate full-year revenue guidance of $25M; 1H15 revenue totaled $9.8M.
    • Between them, the FirstVU body camera and DVM-800 in-car video system accounted for 55% of revenue vs. 54% in Q1 and 45% Y/Y. Over 2K FirstVu units were sold, and sales for DGLY's DVM-250 event recorder line rose over 125% Y/Y. DVM-800 and FirstVu orders are expected to accelerate in 2H15.
    • Gross margin was 54.9%, up from Q1's depressed 38.9% (affected by production issues) and down slightly from Q2 2014's 55.9%. Operating expenses rose 35% Y/Y to $3.9M. Ahead of a $12M stock/warrant offering (net proceeds of $11.2M) DGLY ended Q2 with just $671K in cash.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:47 PM
  • AXP

    American Express +2.8%; activist reportedly takes $1B stake (updated)

    • Bloomberg reports activist ValueAct Capital has taken a $1B stake in American Express (NYSE:AXP).
    • Shares have risen above $77 in response. They closed yesterday just $0.70 above a 52-week low of $74.30.
    • Update (2:08PM ET): AmEx says it has been speaking with ValueAct, and looks forward to "continuing a constructive dialogue. Shares are now up 5.4%.
    • Update 2: The full story is up. Bloomberg reports AmEx "isn't yet a core active target of ValueAct," while adding ValueAct "sees AmEx as a quality business with growth potential."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:33 PM | 21 Comments
  • TWOU

    2U up 14.9% on Q2 beat, strong full-year outlook

    • With a Q2 beat in tow, 2U (NASDAQ:TWOU) now expects 2015 revenue of $147.4M-$148.3M (34% growth at the midpoint), up from prior guidance of $145.6M-$147.4M and above a $147.1M consensus. Full-year adjusted net loss guidance is now at -$16.3M to -$17.2M vs. a prior -$17.2M to -$18.7M.
    • Q3 revenue guidance of $35.9M-$36.3M is slightly below a $37.2M consensus. Adjusted net loss guidance is at -$7.6M to -$8M.
    • The cloud online learning software provider now expects at least 6 new university program launches in 2016. 5,482 students have thus far graduated from 10 2U-powered programs.
    • Shares have jumped to new highs.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:18 PM
  • ELON

    Echelon up 18.2% after Q2 beat; reverse split, strategic review planned

    • Along with its Q2 results, Echelon (NASDAQ:ELON) has announced it plans to seek shareholder approval for a reverse split (expected to be 1:10) to regain Nasdaq minimum bid compliance. No word yet on the split date.
    • The industrial automation hardware/software provider also says it plans to "consider a wide range of available options, including, among other things, partnerships, strategic business model alternatives, recapitalization, disposition of one or more corporate assets, or a possible business combination or sale of the Company, in addition to continued pursuit of the Company as a stand-alone entity." Goldman has been hired to advise.
    • Q3 guidance is for revenue of $9.5M-$10.3M and EPS of -$0.02 to -$0.04, favorable to a consensus of $9.5M and -$0.06. Echelon notes it saw strong demand for its networked lighting control offerings in Q2, and had a "meaningful design win" for its building automation business.
    • Echelon ended Q2 with $26.5M in cash/short-term investments, and no debt.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • ERII

    Energy Recovery +4.5% after smaller than expected loss

    • Energy Recovery (ERII +4.5%) moves higher after reporting a lighter than expected Q2 loss but still generating a loss for the sixth straight quarter and in 16 of the last 18 quarters.
    • ERII benefited from mega-project shipments, offset by higher operating expenses largely related to the CEO transition; its oil and gas segment recorded no revenues, with its only customer having terminated its product lease at the end of 2014.
    • Wedbush maintains its Underperform rating on the stock with a $2 price target, saying that although ERII management indicated during its earnings call that its desal business was a cash cow, it had "hardly demonstrated that the business can consistently generate cash."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • SFUN

    SouFun down 2.9% post-earnings; IDG/Carlyle/management investing up to $1B

    • Along with its Q2 results, SouFun (NYSE:SFUN) announces investment firms IDG and Carlyle, along with certain members of management (mainly founder/CEO Vincent Mo) are investing up to $1B. Half the investment will be in stock, and half via convertible notes.
    • The stock will be sold at $7.45, or $0.04 above Thursday's close. The notes will sport a 1.5% interest rate, and a conversion price of $9.13/share (22.5% above the stock purchase price).
    • With a Q2 beat on the books, SouFun is hiking its full-year revenue guidance to $843.4M (+20% Y/Y) from $808.3M. But that's still slightly below an $844.8M consensus.
    • E-commerce service revenue rose 103% Y/Y in Q2 to $78M, and value-added service revenue rose 43.2% to $8.9M. However, marketing service (ad) revenue fell 16.5% to $101.2M, and listing service revenue (hurt by fee cuts) fell 30.5% to $58.3M.     • "We’re reducing ratings and/or price targets on Avago, Fairchild, Infineon, Intel, Micron, Texas Instruments and Xilinx owing to industry reports key China-based mobile and comm. infrastructure suppliers are pushing out orders," writes Drexel Hamilton's Rick Whittington. For now, Micron (NASDAQ:MU) is the only name in the group seeing a 2%+ decline. The Nasdaq is down 0.7%.
    • Whittington, a long-time chip stock bull, argues "the chip industry has overbuilt and overstocked for a China OEM community that is struggling to work off inventories," and that OEMs such as Huawei, ZTE, and Xiaomi are pushing out orders. A slew of chipmakers have reported seeing high Chinese inventories this earnings season.
    • Nonetheless, Whittington thinks macro conditions in the U.S., Europe, Japan, Korea, and India remain healthy. He also notes the iPhone 6S and other major phone launches could absorb some excess inventory.
    • Regarding Micron, which Whittington upgraded to Buy just 10 days ago (in response to the 3D XPoint reveal), he reports seeing further DRAM spot price declines and reports of new contract price cuts in August, something which leads him to think PC demand remains soft. Micron rallied earlier this week on a report Samsung is slashing PC DRAM output and shifting capacity towards mobile DRAM, and has notified OEMs it won't be cutting prices in August.
    • Some of Whittington's concerns about chip demand/inventories have arguably been priced in: The Philadelphia Semi Index (NASDAQ:SOXX) is down 16% from a June peak of $101.80.

    Himax +7.7% after sales miss, soft guidance; LCoS/WLO "inflection point" expected

    • In addition to posting a Q2 revenue miss to go with in-line EPS, Himax (NASDAQ:HIMX) is guiding for Q3 revenue to drop 5%-9% Q/Q and EPS of $0.01-$0.016, soundly below a consensus for 21% Q/Q revenue growth (to $204.8M) and EPS of $0.08. But with many chipmakers possessing strong mobile and/or Chinese exposure having already guided light, a soft Q3 forecast was expected.
    • Q2 commentary: Himax notes LCD driver demand from branded Chinese smartphone OEMs "rebounded strongly" in Q2, but was offset by Samsung's decision to "strategically increase the weight of AMOLED panels in their smartphone product portfolio." The company is working on OLED drivers, and expects to ship them in 2H15 to Korean and Chinese clients (previous).

      TV driver sales benefited from share gains at Chinese panel makers and rising 4K TV shipments. Tablet driver sales stabilized, and automotive driver sales remained strong. Non-driver sales (image sensor, touch controllers, LCoS, etc.) were affected "weakness in the China market, particularly in the smartphone and tablet segments."
    • Business outlook: TV driver sales are expected to drop Q/Q in Q3, and PC-related driver sales remain weak. Nonetheless, Himax expects positive 2015 growth for its large-panel driver business. The company is counting on 1080p/2K drivers (they carry higher ASPs), OLED drivers, and TDDI (integrated touch controller/driver) ICs to boost mobile sales, and for auto growth to remain strong.

      New customers are expected to boost image sensor sales, and (notably) Himax expects its LCoS microdisplay and wafer-level optics (WLO) businesses to "hit an inflection point" this year. A new manufacturing/office facility (initial investment of $40M) is being developed to help meet demand.
    • Q2 numbers: Small/medium-panel driver IC sales -22.6% Y/Y to $82.8M. Large-panel driver ICs +6.9% to $54.3M. Non-driver products -16.8% to $32.1M. Gross margin fell 190 bps Q/Q and 40 bps Y/Y to 23.8%. GAAP operating expenses rose 8.3% Y/Y to $31.4M. Himax ended Q2 with $164.5M in cash, $130M in restricted cash, and $130M in short-term debt.
